lines.text: All I needed was that girl.
Listen, you can write her off your next year's income tax as an unavoidable loss.
She trembled! She fluttered!
I know. But she'll flutter just as well tomorrow.

Oh, no, she won't; not her. She's got 'conscience' written all over her face. At this moment, she is cooling off - like some beautiful volcano that has decided not to wipe out a lot of Italian villages.

[Talking on the phone]
Hello. Hello? What? Oh, ha-ha, no, No, not tonight. I'm going to that Freelinghouser ball. Yeah. No, I can't, I-I stood her up once before, I can't do that. What? I know it's insane but, it might be fun. Ha-ha. My costume's beginning to fall off already, I think everyone else's will too!
Listen, I tell you what. We'll go up to my sister Sylvia's. There's some fun going on up there! Do you like mad parties?
Well, yes, I-I think I do. Thank you very much.
Good! What's your name?
Rexford.
Rexford... well, you run along home and get on a nice little dinner dress and pick me up in an hour. How's that?
Right!
Right! No, wrong! I'll pick you up. That'll be good and step on it!
Were you really the beetle?
I was the beetle.
How did you know I wanted a highball?
Just instinct.
Sweet.
And you too.
May I?
If you want to, old beetle.
[Kiss]
Mary, this is it!
What?
Us!
Us? You mean, me, Lady Rexford?
Yes, dear!
Oh, darling, after all those things I told you about me? Think now, think hard.
I have thought. It's all forgotten! Oh, isn't it?
Yes, if you say so. Buried and forgotten. Only you in the world. Oh, are you sure you can forgive it all?
Forgiven!
Forgiven? Alright! From now on, a ring in the nose and a beating every Saturday night, please. Ha-ha.
Oh, his father! He was such a gay old buck. Oh, the naughty old devil.
You cheeky little brute!
Oh, oh! Oh, I've got a pain.
It's the lobster.
Not at all! It's not in my tummy, it's in my heart! It's because you're so cruel to me, Bertie!
Aunt Hetty, you're very naughty.
Of course, I am. Why not?
Why not. I was once.
Hmmm. I'm sure you were.
My dear gal, come with me to Cannes!
What?
Come and stay with me at Cannes!
Oh, that sounds divine!
You need sunshine and laughter and a coat of tan.
Get the behind me Satan.
You need music!
And do I know Tommy? The old slouch, where is he?
He's in bed with his miseries.
With who?
No names, please - even among cads.
Come on you, chaperone me. I'll get him out! He looked my way once in New York.
Lucky you.
Now, what does that mean in American, look my way?
That means making a pass, darling. Making a pass!
See that the lady has nothing that she wants, Erskine. I'll return in a jiffy.
You'll never be missed.
Ha-ha. He's a scream.
See these gray hairs? Try living with him for a week.
Might be stimulating.
Look at me. I-I'm stimulated.
Oh! Is that what you call it?
Oh. Oh. Oh my, oh my, oh my. What an age. What a world.
What's wrong with it? I find it a very pleasant world.
It's all part of the coming of the great catastrophe.
What is?
When girls like you turn out to be prudes!
Bertie, they'll be alright.
Hetty's responsible for her.
Oh, Bertsie, you have no romance.
No. Come.
I'd love to!
A leopard cannot change its spots. No more can you, duckie.
Can't a woman forget her past, whatever its been, when she marries and settles down?
Ha-ha-ha. You're mad! Just beautifully batty! You're always reaching out for something, somewhere, some how.
If you'd only be true to yourself. Listen. Listen to those birds up there. They don't have to drink to be gay. That don't have to doll up and gab a lot of nonsense!
We could be happy, too, Mary. Two people like us.
I am happy.
No, I mean two kindred spirits, like you and me.
How?

They could, eh, they could sleep all day. They could get up just when the evening was gonna get gay and they could dance and take long walks into the moonlight. Then, back and change and out on horses and riding into the dawn. Just when everybody else was waking up to face the day, they could be flitting in and out of warm shower baths and pulling down the blinds on trouble and bores and telephones. Then, they'd be up in the evening and drink steaming hot coffee and pull up the shades and let that ol' moon in again. It would be paradise, wouldn't it? They'd be children of the night.

[Smiling]
Satan!
Forget all that solid routine that they call living. Spread your wings and flutter with me sometimes.
Ha-ha. I forgot how to flutter.
I can teach you! Wouldn't it be fun! Wouldn't it be marvelous! Think of the thrill of knowing that just around the corner there was fun and laughter.
Don't make an ass out of yourself!
Do you speak French, Madam?
I do, but I'm not in the mood. What is it?
Well, you might have been killed, I suppose you know that.
Would you really care? Really?
Of course. What do you think I'm made of?
Rainbows.

[Looking at her daughter's drawing]
What is that? How can you have a horse without a tail? Ha-ha. You silly willy!
Oh, no, Sweetheart, I'm sorry, too. I-I didn't mean to blow up. I made myself, promise myself, that I wouldn't.
Did you? I don't mind. You should blow up. I want you to blow up.
Well, go on - darling.
Don't say darling like that, darling.
And now I'll tell you the truth, judge. Ha-ha. The whole truth and nothing but the truth. So help me.
I suppose it is amusing. It makes me a little ill.
Slap me in the face, shout, knock me down, but, don't keep this up. I was wrong, I know it. But, I'm in tact if that means anything to you.
You make it sound quite remarkable.
In New York, you were the kind of girl that didn't stop at a kiss!
Well, Mary, if he won't believe you, why should he take me for a Gideon Bible? I don't look like one, do I?
So, men must work and women must - what?
Since I've been back, all I can find is a restless, jumpy, affected woman.
I had to do something. I couldn't keep following you around the house, on my knees, waiting for you to come out of this coma.
Have a drink?
Love to!
Name it!
Eh, French 75.
Same here. French 75, boom!
Boom yourself! And everyone else.
That a girl.
No man's gonna let me or not let me do anything ever again.
